content: The Transition toward Excellence, Achievement, and Mobility through Empowerment Act of 2011, also known as the TEAM-Empowerment Act of 2011, includes provisions for individualized transition plans and transition planning services administrative units. The Act's findings and purposes are outlined in Section 2. Congress finds that evidence-based research has shown that youth with significant disabilities benefit from inclusive education, work experience, and paid work while in school, leading to better postsecondary outcomes and sustainable employment. Additionally, higher rates of self-determination for individuals with disabilities and their families result in improved outcomes. Regulations allowing flexibility in blending government funds for seamless transition strategies lead to better outcomes for individuals with significant disabilities. Regulations and processes allowing flexibility in blending government funds for seamless, collaborative strategies during the transition process lead to better outcomes for individuals with significant disabilities. Agency officials involved in providing supports and services during a youth's transition into adulthood need additional training to address the individual transition needs of students with significant disabilities. The Act aims to create a holistic system for successful transition of youth with significant disabilities into adulthood, focusing on high expectations, equality of opportunity, full participation, self-determination, and informed choice. Create a holistic system with partners to support the successful transition of youth with disabilities into adulthood, focusing on high expectations, equality of opportunity, self-determination, and post-secondary options leading to competitive employment and economic self-sufficiency. Promote innovative strategies for academic, professional, and social inclusion, along with long-term supports and services. Promote innovative strategies for academic, professional, and social inclusion, as well as long-term supports and services to ensure full integration into the community setting. Better define and coordinate specific services for the effective transition of youth with significant disabilities, and eliminate barriers to collaboration among stakeholders to improve transition opportunities for these youth. Subtitle F--Adult Transition System is added to Title I of the Developmental Disabilities Assistance and Bill of Rights Act of 2000, including definitions in Section 171. The Secretary will provide grants to States for carrying out activities under this subtitle, with payments allocated based on the number of individuals to be served in each State. "Individualized transition plans are outlined in Section 173." Each State receiving assistance under this subtitle must develop an individual transition plan for individuals with developmental disabilities transitioning from secondary school to adulthood. The plan aims to coordinate services for integrated employment, postsecondary education, independent living, and community engagement. The individual transition plan (ITP) is intended to assist individuals with developmental disabilities in achieving outcomes such as integrated employment, postsecondary education, independent living, and community engagement. The ITP must be coordinated with any pre-existing transition services, developed within 30 days of exiting secondary school, and align with the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act. The individualized education program is developed for individuals with disabilities before exiting secondary school, pursuant to the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act. It must be developed within 30 days of graduation, applicable until the individual turns 26, reviewed annually, and updated as needed during in-person meetings led by the State's administrative unit for intellectual and developmental disabilities. The individualized education program is developed for individuals with disabilities before exiting secondary school, pursuant to the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act. It must be applicable until the individual turns 26, reviewed annually, and updated as needed during in-person meetings led by the State's administrative unit for intellectual and developmental disabilities, involving key stakeholders. The transition services for individuals with disabilities must involve key stakeholders such as the individual, family, transition broker, State vocational rehabilitation agency representative, relevant service providers, and transition coordinator from the local educational agency. The ITP shall include strategies for implementing effective service models and practices involving key stakeholders such as the individual, family, transition coordinator, assistive technology experts, and workforce development representatives. An Individualized Transition Plan (ITP) should include strategies for implementing effective service models and practices involving key stakeholders such as the individual, family, transition coordinator, assistive technology experts, and workforce development representatives. The plan should address postsecondary educational experiences, career preparation, work-based learning, development and leadership, connecting activities, and family involvement and support needs. The Individualized Transition Plan (ITP) should focus on 5 key areas: postsecondary educational experiences, career preparation, work-based learning, development and leadership, connecting activities, and family involvement and support. It should also aim to promote economic self-sufficiency through asset development goals and tools like tax benefits and education incentives. The State and its agencies will address 5 key areas to meet needs and promote economic self-sufficiency through asset development goals and specific tools like tax benefits, work incentives, matched savings plans, education financing, and budget management strategies. The transition planning and services administrative unit is outlined in section 174. Each State receiving assistance under this subtitle must establish a transition planning and services (TPS) administrative unit within the State intellectual and developmental disabilities agency. The primary focus of the TPS unit is to help individuals with developmental disabilities transition from the secondary school system to adulthood by developing and implementing individual transition plans (ITPs). The TPS administrative unit in each State is responsible for developing and implementing individual transition plans (ITPs) to help individuals with developmental disabilities transition from the secondary school system to adulthood. Transition brokers are employed to facilitate coordination among State agencies. Transition brokers are employed by the TPS administrative unit to facilitate coordination among State agencies and provide assistance to individuals with developmental disabilities in navigating support services. Transition brokers in the TPS administrative unit assist individuals with developmental disabilities in navigating support services by providing expertise and assistance in developing Individualized Transition Plans (ITPs). Eligibility for this role requires possessing specific qualifications related to individuals with disabilities. Transition brokers in the TPS administrative unit must have expertise in developmental disabilities, benefits planning, transition services, employment, and negotiation with State stakeholders. Transition brokers in the TPS administrative unit should have experience in developmental disabilities, benefits planning, transition services, employment, job development, and negotiation with State stakeholders. They should also possess knowledge of workforce development, vocational rehabilitation, and tools for asset development and economic self-sufficiency. Transition brokers in the TPS administrative unit should have expertise in workforce development, vocational rehabilitation, asset development tools, economic self-sufficiency, self-direction, and person-centered planning processes. The TPS administrative unit transition brokers should have expertise in workforce development, vocational rehabilitation, asset development tools, economic self-sufficiency, self-direction, person-centered planning processes, tax benefits, work incentives, matched savings plans, education financing, budget management, money, and credit. The TPS administrative unit assigns a transition broker to individuals with developmental disabilities upon selection by the individual or their family, and approval by the State agency. The unit also provides strategies and training for self-advocacy, self-determination skills, and peer mentoring. The TPS administrative unit offers strategies and training for self-advocacy, self-determination skills, and peer mentoring to individuals with developmental disabilities and their families. They also provide effective information and resources to improve advocacy and negotiation abilities. The TPS administrative unit offers strategies and training for self-advocacy, self-determination skills, and peer mentoring to individuals with developmental disabilities and their families. They provide information on Federal and State services, supports, regulations, asset development, insurance, benefit programs, financial savings tools, and eligibility criteria for means-tested services. The State intellectual and developmental disabilities agency facilitates collaboration among multiple agencies in states receiving assistance under this subtitle. Information on Federal and State services, supports, regulations, asset development, insurance, benefit programs, financial savings tools, and eligibility criteria for means-tested services is provided and updated quarterly for individuals with developmental disabilities and their families. The State intellectual and developmental disabilities agency facilitates collaboration among key State agencies to coordinate services for individuals with developmental disabilities during the transition into adulthood. The Secretary is required to submit an annual report to Congress evaluating the implementation and effectiveness of the subtitle. This includes assessing the number of individuals with Individual Transition Plans (ITPs) in each State, progress in implementing ITP objectives, and details on employment status, education, income, race, gender, and residence for individuals with ITPs. Authorization of $50,000,000 annually for fiscal years 2012 through 2016 to implement the subtitle.
